description: The VCA6 show dives into data center virtualization fundamentals and featuring vSphere 6 as the solution.  It helps the candidate of the VCA6-DCV certification by discussing and demonstrating VMWare’s data center virtualization technology.  The demonstrations and the discussion in each episode go into to identifying the technical requirements for managing the VMWare vSphere 6 environment.  The segments focus on data center challenges and understanding what VMWare products and solutions can be used to meet those requirements.
name: VMware Certified Associate 6 VCA6-DCV
subtitle: Data Center Virtualization

episodes.description: The VCA6 show dives into data center virtualization fundamentals and featuring vSphere 6 as the solution. It helps the candidate of the VCA6-DCV certification by discussing and demonstrating VMWare’s data center virtualization technology. The demonstrations and the discussion in each episode go into to identifying the technical requirements for managing the VMWare vSphere 6 environment. The segments focus on data center challenges and understanding what VMWare products and solutions can be used to meet those requirements.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:03.701
[SOUND] In this segment,

2
00:00:03.701 --> 00:00:09.603
we're gonna give you a brief overview

3
00:00:09.603 --> 00:00:16.068
of our upcoming VCA6-DCV exam series.

4
00:00:16.068 --> 00:00:19.595
And joining me here to help out with
every endeavors, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:19.595 --> 00:00:22.410
Ronnie, can you help
give us a generalization,

6
00:00:22.410 --> 00:00:24.769
a general overview of what this is about?

7
00:00:24.769 --> 00:00:29.778
>> We take a look at actually trying our
hand here at actually doing the VCA6.

8
00:00:29.778 --> 00:00:33.505
What we're trying to say is that we wanna
get used to the technology that we're

9
00:00:33.505 --> 00:00:36.990
gonna find inside the VMware
especially in vSphere version 6.

10
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:38.330
Normally this is gonna be for

11
00:00:38.330 --> 00:00:43.230
someone that is actually a decision maker
trying to make a move into virtualization

12
00:00:43.230 --> 00:00:46.310
thinking that it's something that they
might wanna do for their data center or

13
00:00:46.310 --> 00:00:49.050
somebody that's helping to
make that decision as well.

14
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:51.670
And they need to get more
familiar with the topics so

15
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:54.650
that they have a general understanding and
they can actually do a little bit

16
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:58.350
more research into it, to see if
this is the way that they wanna go.

17
00:00:58.350 --> 00:01:01.797
It really does help out, of course,
if you have a technical background,

18
00:01:01.797 --> 00:01:05.687
you've been working in IT for a little bit
of time, but there is no real requirement

19
00:01:05.687 --> 00:01:08.488
as far as the certification goes,
but it really does help.

20
00:01:08.488 --> 00:01:12.331
Because some of the concepts will cover
of course our general concepts that we'll

21
00:01:12.331 --> 00:01:14.590
find throughout the entire IT industry.

22
00:01:14.590 --> 00:01:18.880
>> So the intended audience for this
series is gonna be, anybody that wants to

23
00:01:18.880 --> 00:01:23.880
know more about virtualization in general
and maybe even the VMware products itself.

24
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:24.750
>> It really is it.

25
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:29.130
Really does help us to be able to see how
those VMware products hook together and

26
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:30.540
be able to work together.

27
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:35.301
Understand the technical requirements
behind them especially in terms of VMware,

28
00:01:35.301 --> 00:01:37.110
vSphere 6.

29
00:01:37.110 --> 00:01:41.020
So once we have that understanding, that
makes it easier for the decision maker and

30
00:01:41.020 --> 00:01:43.900
makes it easier for somebody at
least trying to administrate or

31
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:48.580
get their hands into the administration
of these sphere 6, as well.

32
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:49.238
>> All right, Ronnie.

33
00:01:49.238 --> 00:01:54.240
Does this series, is it going to
correlate with any exams or tests?

34
00:01:54.240 --> 00:01:55.238
>> It really does.

35
00:01:55.238 --> 00:01:58.150
Inside of VMware, of course,
they have a learning division,

36
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:02.160
which means they also have training,
and they also have certifications.

37
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:07.409
So when we start taking a look at it,
what this actual series is going

38
00:02:07.409 --> 00:02:12.398
to help you out in, is for
you to be able to earn your VCA6-DCV.

39
00:02:12.398 --> 00:02:13.720
Now, what does that actually mean?

40
00:02:13.720 --> 00:02:17.410
Let's take a look at my screen here for
a moment and that will help us out.

41
00:02:17.410 --> 00:02:19.330
So when we take a look here,

42
00:02:19.330 --> 00:02:24.030
VMware Certified Associate 6
Data Center Virtualization Fundamentals.

43
00:02:24.030 --> 00:02:26.810
So the term fundamentals let's

44
00:02:26.810 --> 00:02:30.320
hey, here is the exam that
we are actually going for.

45
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:32.560
And it's actually a fundamentals exam.

46
00:02:32.560 --> 00:02:35.400
So it actually rests heavily
more on the concepts.

47
00:02:35.400 --> 00:02:38.710
And the technologies in terms of
identification and understanding

48
00:02:38.710 --> 00:02:43.300
the benefits and understanding solutions
that VMware provides rather than the idea

49
00:02:43.300 --> 00:02:47.360
of configuration and of mastery of
all the programs that you see there.

50
00:02:47.360 --> 00:02:53.660
This matches up to an exam number
right here which is 1V0-601.

51
00:02:53.660 --> 00:02:56.670
And that's what you actually wanna
take a look at when you start

52
00:02:56.670 --> 00:02:58.840
to earn that certification.

53
00:02:58.840 --> 00:03:02.290
Of course, that means that if you're
going to earn that certification,

54
00:03:02.290 --> 00:03:05.600
you need to of course sign up and
be able to pass it, as well.

55
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:08.613
So some of the details in
that is gonna actually be,

56
00:03:08.613 --> 00:03:11.830
well, this, the exam that you take
is gonna be 50 questions long.

57
00:03:13.040 --> 00:03:18.077
And you'll have a 75 minute duration to
build to take that exam and your passing

58
00:03:18.077 --> 00:03:23.263
score is a 300, now they don’t tell you
what the upper number is but that's what

59
00:03:23.263 --> 00:03:28.548
the passing score is gonna be as a 300 out
of those 50 questions when you do that.

60
00:03:28.548 --> 00:03:33.017
Now, the other thing occurs that most
people are concerned about them,

61
00:03:33.017 --> 00:03:36.532
is that when you take a look
there is a price associated and

62
00:03:36.532 --> 00:03:41.364
currently the price associated with
this is gonna be a about $120, US, so

63
00:03:41.364 --> 00:03:46.230
make sure you note that when you
actually go to pay for the exam.

64
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:50.350
So this exam is actually the current one
that gives you that associate level in

00:03:50.350 --> 00:03:52.060

66
00:03:52.060 --> 00:03:57.060
And it's actually very easy for you to

00:03:57.060 --> 00:03:59.160
Now, before you actually
say anything like, man,

do I need to go to a testing center?

You really don't because this
particular exam is non-proctored, and

that means you can take it online.

71

Now, does that mean wow,
it's an online exam, can I cheat?

00:04:10.176 --> 00:04:14.682
Well, no, you really can't and
the reason why is that they actually take

73

74
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:22.250
So don't think that it's actually
just unproctored and that means, hey,

75
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:23.800
it's an open book exam.

76
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:27.020
It means that time limit is actually
something they follow by very strictly and

77
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:31.350
they do take screenshots of
what's going on during the exam.

78
00:04:31.350 --> 00:04:33.310
So they'll know if you're

79

going through web pages and
when you're doing that.

80
00:04:35.430 --> 00:04:37.710
But yes, you won't be able to do that.

81

Now, when you register for

You'll actually notice that,

83

So if you do a search from your favorite

you actually bring up this Register Now,

account, you'll just walk through, pick
the language that you want this to be in.

87
00:05:00.456 --> 00:05:04.278
And notice there's three languages,

88
00:05:04.278 --> 00:05:06.719
If you actually happen to
be proficient in all three,

89
00:05:06.719 --> 00:05:10.083
I took mine in English cuz I'm not
proficient in Japanese, I know a little

90
00:05:10.083 --> 00:05:13.555
bit of Chinese, but overall English is
actually gonna be my base language,

91
00:05:13.555 --> 00:05:16.580
you'll be able to register for
it, and here's the key.

92
00:05:16.580 --> 00:05:19.582
You don't just get to register for

93
00:05:19.582 --> 00:05:23.450
what they actually intend for you to do is

when you are ready for that exam, you

And it gives you two

So you actually see that from

there's gonna be a little button

So if you accidentally click on that and

So be very careful when you choose

101
00:05:48.600 --> 00:05:53.730
Now, the neat thing is, when you actually

00:05:53.730 --> 00:05:59.430

So I recommend that you not click

00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:03.090

00:06:03.090 --> 00:06:05.700
You can, you can take a look at it and

00:06:05.700 --> 00:06:08.068
But notice they actually

109
00:06:14.850 --> 00:06:17.700
>> Ronnie, you actually hit on a really

111
00:06:23.390 --> 00:06:26.480
>> Well, when it comes down to it,
remember that when we take a look at this,

we actually will follow the exam topics

00:06:30.280 --> 00:06:34.520
So what we're actually going to do here

00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:36.870
We'll follow these exam topics along and

115
00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:41.000
we'll see that there's some overlap to it
and which we'll just cover once instead of

116
00:06:41.000 --> 00:06:43.090
actually going through

117
00:06:43.090 --> 00:06:47.460
So for example, explaining
the data virtualization concepts,

00:06:47.460 --> 00:06:50.820
identifying those typical
challenges is pretty much key.

119
00:06:50.820 --> 00:06:54.720
And we'll take a look at things like,
what is the data center itself and

120
00:06:54.720 --> 00:06:59.535
what is data center virtualization, we'll
talk about the benefits of virtualization

121
00:06:59.535 --> 00:07:03.588
as well as some of the common components

122
00:07:03.588 --> 00:07:07.488
And then, of course, we'll take a look
at the challenges that VMware helps us

123
00:07:07.488 --> 00:07:10.738
to resolve by taking a look at some

124
00:07:10.738 --> 00:07:12.980
we'll make sure we enumerate those.

125
00:07:12.980 --> 00:07:17.060
Take a look at management challenges,
scalability, and optimization challenges

126
00:07:17.060 --> 00:07:22.230
that we tend to actually have to face,
and where VMware helps us to face those.

127
00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:25.200
And then, of course,
we get into the meat of the product,

128
00:07:25.200 --> 00:07:29.375
which is to get more familiar

129
00:07:29.375 --> 00:07:31.774
vSphere 6, and you'll see us in here,

130
00:07:31.774 --> 00:07:36.645
that we'll go over storage technologies,
networking, resource management,

131
00:07:36.645 --> 00:07:40.458
availability and even some of
the different products that we may

132
00:07:40.458 --> 00:07:43.938
not have covered anywhere else
during the entire course.

133
00:07:43.938 --> 00:07:47.612
And then, in the end, we'll take a look
at some of the different challenges that

134
00:07:47.612 --> 00:07:50.490
happen when we start talking
about business challenges here.

135
00:07:50.490 --> 00:07:53.780
And usually some of the business
challenges happen to deal with size.

136
00:07:53.780 --> 00:07:57.930
What size is your organization and
what we actually have to expect from that.

137
00:07:57.930 --> 00:07:58.810
The good thing is,

138
00:07:58.810 --> 00:08:01.870
during the entire course, you'll probably
end up seeing that we'll cover just about

139
00:08:01.870 --> 00:08:06.510
every single challenge that we normally
will face in the course itself.

140
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:10.100
And so, at the end it's really just
a review of everything that we need.

141
00:08:10.100 --> 00:08:12.320
So when you start taking a look here,

142
00:08:12.320 --> 00:08:16.280
some of the things that you want to
consider as you actually are preparing,

143
00:08:16.280 --> 00:08:20.090
and getting ready for
this course is the terminology itself.

144
00:08:20.090 --> 00:08:23.280
Making sure, of course, that if you
know some of the ideas and some

145
00:08:23.280 --> 00:08:28.370
of the concepts, make sure you learn the
VMware idea and the concepts there, too.

146
00:08:28.370 --> 00:08:31.490
And of course, make sure you actually
know the names of these products,

147
00:08:31.490 --> 00:08:34.760
cuz this is a big one that you
have to pay attention to, as well.

148
00:08:34.760 --> 00:08:39.310
So this is why it's not the most
technically challenging exam before us,

149
00:08:39.310 --> 00:08:43.180
but it is actually an exam that will
challenge you as far as the number of

150
00:08:43.180 --> 00:08:45.210
products that we go through.

151
00:08:45.210 --> 00:08:50.230
And yes, if you want to pass the exam, you
got to know those products, those features

152
00:08:50.230 --> 00:08:54.360
and even some of the benefits of those,
so make sure you pay careful attention

153
00:08:54.360 --> 00:08:58.860
during the entirety of this series
as we actually go through this.

154
00:08:58.860 --> 00:09:02.360
Now, the other thing is,
right here on the preparation,

155
00:09:02.360 --> 00:09:06.500
they have in that nice three-hour
training video for you to go through.

156
00:09:06.500 --> 00:09:08.570
And this is their recommended training,
and

157
00:09:08.570 --> 00:09:10.950
they even have a practice exam for you.

158
00:09:10.950 --> 00:09:12.780
And all of this is for free.

159
00:09:12.780 --> 00:09:16.916
Now, on the practice exam, it'll give
you 99 times to go through this.

160
00:09:16.916 --> 00:09:17.716
Now, what does that mean?

161
00:09:17.716 --> 00:09:21.250
It doesn't mean it's the exact same exam,
so you gotta be careful.

162
00:09:21.250 --> 00:09:25.950
Use it only to help you assess in areas
that you are having problems in, and

163
00:09:25.950 --> 00:09:28.520
you'll see that if you ever
get 100% score, you're done.

164
00:09:28.520 --> 00:09:30.470
It won't let you take it again.

165
00:09:30.470 --> 00:09:32.250
So it'll lock you out at that point.

166
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:36.840
So always at the end, it even tells you,
at least make one answer wrong if you're

167
00:09:36.840 --> 00:09:41.270
not taking the exam immediately, and
that way you can always go back through.

168
00:09:41.270 --> 00:09:43.730
Use it to actually find areas
that you're weak in and then,

169
00:09:43.730 --> 00:09:46.610
once you actually find those weak areas,
make sure you go back and

170
00:09:46.610 --> 00:09:49.920
study them a bit more in
depth when you do so.

171
00:09:49.920 --> 00:09:54.080
The other thing that I want you to be able
to take advantage of, is really this last

172
00:09:54.080 --> 00:10:00.350
one right here where it says,
Test Drive VMware vSphere Environment.

173
00:10:01.390 --> 00:10:04.590
This will give you access
to a nice virtual lab

174
00:10:04.590 --> 00:10:09.060
that will allow you to test drive vSphere
and take a look at all the different

175
00:10:09.060 --> 00:10:12.720
components that we talked about
throughout this particular series.

176
00:10:12.720 --> 00:10:14.180
It's really gonna help you out.

177
00:10:14.180 --> 00:10:17.560
The more that you get hands on with it,
the better off you're gonna actually

178
00:10:17.560 --> 00:10:21.400
be as you take a look at those different
products that are actually offered, and

179
00:10:21.400 --> 00:10:23.890
what vSphere really wants
you to be able to do.

180
00:10:23.890 --> 00:10:28.490
So there is a lot of information, but I
think we're actually ready to get started.

181
00:10:28.490 --> 00:10:30.680
>> Well, Ronnie, thanks so
much for that overview and

182
00:10:30.680 --> 00:10:33.730
that general assessment of what we
can expect in this upcoming series.

183
00:10:33.730 --> 00:10:37.354
And if it sounds like something
that you might be interested in,

184
00:10:37.354 --> 00:10:40.790
then we look forward to seeing
you in the upcoming episodes.

185
00:10:40.790 --> 00:10:44.447
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through a review of virtualization concepts to prepare you for the VCA6-DCV exam. They begin with the physical hardware and how hypervisors access it. Then they describe the two different types of hypervisors; the Hosted(Type-II) and the Bare-Metal(Type-I). Finally they explore some of the advantages of implementing a virtualized environment.
episodes.title: Review Virtualization Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their review of virtualization concepts, starting here with the problems that virtualization solves. Next, they discuss what devices can be virtualized and what v-technologies VMware provides for that task. Finally, they show the many benefits of virtualization which includes, availability, scalability, optimization, and management.
episodes.title: Review Virtualization Concepts Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the benefits Data Center Virtualization. These advantages include lowered cost, maintenance, and space to support your Data Center. It also allows for a highly available environment which increases your business continuity and reducing your downtime.
episodes.title: Explain DCV Benefits

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss some common challenges when managing a datacenter and look at how VMware addresses them. First they look at the different editions of VMware vSphere to familiarize you with them. Then they jump right into datacenter challenges like licensing, scalability, and downtime; explaining VMware's proposed solutions with vSphere.
episodes.title: Understand DCV Challenges

topics.title: Explain Data Center Virtualization Concepts and Identify Typical Data Center Challenges

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain many of the VMware vSphere technologies. They being by explaining the basics of a VMware environment which includes the ESXi hypervisor, the vSphere client, and the vSphere server. Then they look at migration technologies, starting with vMotion. Next they look at VMware's solutions to grant you High Availability and Fault Tolerance. Finally, they show you how the VMware environment can cluster devices and pool resources like storage.
episodes.title: Describe vSphere Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to identify vSphere storage technologies. They begin by differentiating between physical and virtual storage as well as the going over some of the benefits of virtual storage. They also look at the High Availability features in vSphere and help you contrast/compare the VMFS and NFS datastores.
episodes.title: Identify vSphere Storage Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their look at vSphere Storage Technologies; picking up with explaining Thin Provisioning. Then they explore the capabilities of a Virtual Storage Area Network(SAN) appliance and then Virtual Volume capabilities. Finally, they identify the capabilities of Storage I/O control.
episodes.title: Identify vSphere Storage Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie jump into the exciting world of networking technologies in vSphere. Here they begin by explaining how vSphere connects virtual machines through the Standard and Distributed Virtual Switches. They also introduce you to the virtual switch components, being the Management Plane and the Data Plane. Finally, they look at switch policies and network I/O control.
episodes.title: Identify vSphere Networking Technologies

episodes.description:
Errata:  Ronnie mentions DRS as being Dynamic Resource Scheduler, that is not correct.  It is Distributed Resource Scheduler.  This is an important distinction for the exam please note.    Ronnie was mixing the DPM (Dynamic Power Management) concepts and DRS together, it does happen.
In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through the different resource management technologies in vSphere. They begin by explaining the concept of resource management with regards to your virtualized environment. Then they briefly touch on vRealize. Next, they jump into explaining the different vMotion technologies; Cross vSwitch, Cross vCenter, Long Distance, and Storage vMotion. Finally, they address Distributed Resource Management, Distributed Power Management, and High Availability.
episodes.title: Identify vSphere Resource Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at some of the availability technologies and solutions found in vSphere. The begin by explaining the most commonly used availability system which is backups; specifically vSphere Data Protection. Then they discuss vCloud Air Disaster Recovery and Private Cloud Disaster Recovery. Finally then cover vSphere replication requirements and even show you how to configure High Availability.
episodes.title: Identify vSphere Availability Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore the networking side of VMware by looking at VMware NSX. With NSX you are able to set up a virtualized network of switches, gateways, routers, and even load balancers. Next they focus on exploring the features of vRealize which works to configure operations, monitoring, and alerts, among other things. Finally, they explain the EVO Rack and EVO Rail systems.
episodes.title: Explain DCV Products

topics.title: Identify, Explain and Differentiate VMware vSphere Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie explore and help to identify various virtual infrastructure objects. They will also explain how to identify and differentiate between different objects statuses and conditions as well as a descriptions of the actions that can be applied different statuses or conditions are identified.
episodes.title: Understand Virtual Object Status

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie explore the vSphere web interface used to configure ESXi servers. They explain the function of the different client panes, object navigation, the main workspace, filters, access control, tagging and categorization.
episodes.title: Navigate vSphere Interface

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss the technologies and tools administrators can utilize to monitor hosts running on ESXi. They look at tools like the Client Integration Plugin, how to acquire the plugin and browser support. They also explain the VWWare Remote Console, VMWare tools and how to utilize them.
episodes.title: Monitor ESXi Host and VMs

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss the various operations that can be performed on a VM through the vSphere Web Client. They explain the different power states of a VM and how to identify these states. They look at the different startup options available for VMs on ESXi.
episodes.title: Perform VM Operations

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on the various operations that can be performed on a VM through the vSphere. They will look at vApp operations that can be performed as well as demonstrating operating system installation in Windows and Linux.
episodes.title: Perform VM Operations Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie go over the common business challenges like availability, management, optimization, and scalability; and how to leverage VMware solutions to remediate those issues. They help you discern which solution to use based on business size from small to enterprise.
episodes.title: Apply VMware DCV Solutions

topics.title: Correlate VMware Data Center Virtualization Solutions with Specific Business Challenges
